title.narrative: Social marketing of reproductive health supplies in sub-Saharan Africa
Social marketing of reproductive health supplies in sub-Saharan Africa

description.narrative:
Sida upphandlar en leverantör av social marknadsföring av ett omfattande utbud av sexual och reproduktiv hälsoprodukter. Leverantören skall dessutom erbjuda informationskampanj för att öka efterfrågan för produkterna, utbildning av personal som säljer/sätter in produkterna, kvalitetssäkring, produktregistrering, regionalt mervärde, samt - där möjligt- bidra till lokala och regionala insatser att utöka tillgång till preventivmedel och säkra aborttjänser med hög kvalitet, och för att minska stigma runt dess använding hos sexuellt aktiva ungdomar samt abort.
Målgrupperna är sexuellt aktiva tonåringar (10-19 år), gifta/sammanboende och ogifta unga människor (20-24 år), gifta/sammanboende och ogifta kvinnor och män över 24 år, samt män som har sex med män.
Programmet implementeras 2019-2022.
Det finns tre geografiska komponenter: 1) Ett regionalt program i Väst- och Centralafrika (minst 10/15 länder, därav Mali måste vara ett av länderna), 2) landprogram i Demokratiska Republiken Kongo, Liberia och Mocambique, samt 3) en option för ett regionalt program i 3-5 länder i Östafrika från 2020, vilket innebär en möjlighet för Sida att utvidga kontraktet till att omfatta ytterligare ett regionalt program i Östafrika för upp till 50 MSEK.
Den totala budgeten för programmet (inkluderat optionen) är 365 MSEK.

Sida will procure a supplier to provide social marketing of a comprehensive mix of sexual and reproductive health commodities and devices. Additionally, the supplier will deliver demand generation, training, quality assurance, registration of products, regional added-value, and – where possible – contributions to local and/or regional advocacy efforts to promote access to high-quality contraceptive and safe abortion services and products and to reduce stigma around contraceptive use among unmarried, sexually active young people as well as abortion stigma.
The target groups are Sexually active adolescents (10-19 yrs), Married/cohabiting and unmarried young adults (20-24 yrs), married/cohabiting and unmarried women and men over 24 years, and men who have sex with men.
The program will take place from 2019-2022.
There are three geographical components: 1) A regional West and Central Africa program (at least 10/15 countries, of which Mali must be one), 2) country programs in Democratic Republic of Congo, Liberia and Mozambique, and 3) an option for a regional East African program from 2020 (at least 3 of 5 countries), which will allow Sida to expand the program to another regional program for up to 50 MSEK.
The total budget for the program (including the option) is 365 MSEK.

The expected impact of the programme is to contribute progress towards universal sexual and reproductive health and rights (SDGs 3.1, 3.3, 3.7, 5.6) by increasing women's and girls’ bodily autonomy through providing them with possibilities to make their own fertility choices, and by providing knowledge and opportunities for women, men and young people to protect themselves from STIs and HIV. This will be achieved through providing a programme to socially market sexual and reproductive health commodities and devices in Francophone West and Central Africa (including Mali), DRC, Liberia, Mozambique, Kenya, Ethiopia, Tanzania and Uganda. Impact/Outcomes/Outputs specified in the Terms of Reference: Impact: Suppliers will contribute to progress towards universal sexual and reproductive health and rights, to be measured11 annually by:- Maternal deaths averted- Maternal DALYs averted- Unintended pregnancies averted- Unsafe abortions averted- HIV infections averted- HIV-related DALYs averted- Improved social norms around sexually active adolescents and young people, contraceptive use, and abortion stigma (pre- and post-program) Outcome: Women and girls have the possibility of planning their own fertility, and through giving women, men and young people better means to protect themselves from sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and HIV, to be measured quarterly by Couple years of protection (CYP). Outputs: Output 1: Increased knowledge of SRHR products amongst primary beneficiaries, to be measured by:- Knowledge of contraception and safe abortion methods amongst clients Output 2: Increased demand for SRH products and SRHR services amongst primary beneficiaries, to be measured by:- Condom sales- Contraceptive sales- Safe abortion product and device sales- Comprehensive abortion services provided, where relevant- New acceptors of modern contraception, where relevant Output 3: Better quality SRH services, to be measured by:- Provider and retailer knowledge and attitudes (ie # and % of health care providers pharmacists who give correct information on products)- Number of stock-outs in the distribution chain- Services and programs youth-friendly (ie through mystery clients) Output 4: Increased choice of contraceptive methods, to be measured by:- Commodity method mix at country level and service delivery points- Increased capacity of private sector to provide contraceptives Output 5: Gender transformative and equitable social marketing, to be measured by:- Pro-poor targeting- Gender analysis as part of marketing-strategies- Number and geographic coverage of contraceptive delivery points (services, pharmacies, health shops, outreach) disaggregated by rural-urban and socio-economic status of area.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
Reported results that were achieved by the supplier in 2020 are combined results based on the support through this contribution together with mobilisation of internal resources and additional development partner resources. Sida's contribution to overall results varies depending on the country and markets. As DKT is a social enterprise it pools resources from various donors together with its own resources and the margins from product sales in order to increase demand for, access to, and availability of, contraceptives and medical abortion products.
In 2020 DKT reported that it delivered over 9.4 million CYPs through the sale of more than 125.2 million (male) condoms, 14,100 female condoms, 7.7 million cycles of oral contraception (OC), nearly 7.1 million units of emergency contraception (EC), 4.1 million injectables, 353,000 implants, 730,000 IUDs, nearly 5.7 million misoprostol tablets, 624,000 mifepristone-misoprostol medical abortion (MA) combipacks, and 22,900 manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) kits in the target countries covered by this contribution.
These results helped avert over 1.4 million unintended pregnancies, nearly 2.1 million unsafe abortions, 12,250 maternal deaths and nearly 679,500 maternal disability-adjusted life years (DALYs), 125,000 HIV infections and 1.3 million HIV DALYs.
Results Framework:
Impact:
Progress towards universal sexual and reproductive health and rights:
1) Maternal deaths averted: 12,250 (target 21,049). 58% achievement.
2) Maternal DALYs averted: 679,493 (target 1,192,212). 57% achievement
3) Unintended pregnancies averted: 1,413,608 (target 3,736,519). 38% achievement.
4) Unsafe abortions averted: 2,088,612 (target 3,965,753). 53% achievement.
5) HIV infections averted: 125,137 (target 28,727). 436% achievement.
6) HIV-related DALYs averted: 1,307,189 (target 1,155,460). 113% achievement.
(As with previous reports, the use of the MSI Health Impact Calculator is based on sales of the various contraceptives and medical abortion products rather than actual follow up with client purchases and thus these figures do not necessarily reflect actual numbers, and they include sales to NGOs, public and private sectors. See below for an analysis.)
Outcome:
Women and girls have the possibility of planning their own fertility. And women, men and young people have better means to protect themselves from sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and HIV, measured by Couple years of protection (CYP):
- Total CYPs 2020 = 9,406,846 (target 12,493,591). 75% achievement
Outputs:
Output 1: Increased knowledge of SRHR products amongst primary beneficiaries, measured by knowledge of contraception and safe abortion methods among primary beneficiaries (aged 20 - 30), visitors to Women First Digital (WFD) platforms and interactions on WFD platforms
1) 90% of clients between 20 and 30 who were surveyed answered correctly regarding whether they could name at least two methods of contraception and where they could access contraceptives and safe abortion services (target was 63%).
2) 2,651,425 visits to WFD platforms (against a target of 3,600,000). 74% achievement
3) 55,527 interactions (online chat and using hotline) against a target of 12,500.
Output 2: Increased demand for SRH products and SRHR services among primary beneficiaries, measured by product sales:
1) Condom sales: 125,212,796 (target 128,101,486)
2) Contraceptive sales: 20,018,999 (target 18,572,885)
3) Safe abortion product and device sales: 6,345,668 (target 5,499,871)
4) Comprehensive abortion services provided through DKT and partner clinics: In Ethiopia 11,195 (target 10,000), in Mozambique 57 (target 35,000). N/A in other countries.
5) New acceptors of modern contraception (where DKT and partner clinics): In Ethiopia 52,637 (target 40,000), in Mozambique 20,159 (target 65,000). N/A in other countries.
Output 3: Better quality SRH services, measured by provider knowledge, stock-outs and youth-friendly services:
1) Provider and retailer knowledge and attitudes (ie # and % of health care providers pharmacists who give correct information on products): 75% (target 67%)
2) Number of stock-outs in the distribution chain: average 1 stock-out happened in all countries in 2020 compared to target of 1.
3) Percentage of DKT outlets that provide non-judgemental products and services to young mystery shoppers: 80% of young mystery shoppers considered provider to offer good, knowledgeable service compared to a target of 50%.
In addition, DKT Youth Ambassadors referred over 503,000 new users of SRHR to service delivery outlets for care, more than 41,000 of whom were under 20 years old.
Output 4: Increased choice of contraceptive methods
1) Commodity method mix at country level and service delivery points (measured by outlets carrying at least three DKT products): in total, 26741 outlets carried at least three DKT products (target 8450).
2) Increased capacity of private sector to provide contraceptives (measured by numbers of trained): 6,390 (target 5,143). 133% achievement
Output 5: Gender transformative and equitable social marketing:
1) Pro-poor focus, measured by number of outlets serving clients below poverty line: 48% (target 63%). 76% achievement
2) Gender analysis as part of marketing-strategies, measured by number of gender transformative adverts (based on survey of clients): 80% of DKT adds in all countries (target 71%).
3) Estimated percentage of outlets that provide contraceptives and safe abortion services in areas outside urban areas: 73% (target 71%)
Other results
DKT DRC designed a training programme to educate providers about the ratification of the Maputo protocol and usage of the MA combipack, misoprostol, and MVA kits. The training model combined provincial health leaders and health care providers from the public and private sectors in a one-day capacity building session on product usage. Since the beginning of 2020, DKTs medical liaison team trained 1,825 health care personnel through safe abortion trainings in 37 health zones in the Kinshasa, Kongo Central, Kwilu and Kasai Oriental provinces.
In Liberia, DKTs collaboration with the Ministry of Health, along with the Embassy of Sweden in Liberia and other key stakeholders, helped DKT emerge as the most reliable supplier of SRH commodities in the country during the pandemic. DKT contributed nearly 77% of Liberias government-mandated LARC commodity requirements, the single largest contribution to the countrys SRH commodity needs of any private sector organization.
In Kenya and Uganda, DKT expanded access to SRHR by introducing new brands as well as driving distribution of key products to providers and outlets previously without consistent access. Currently, DKT is the only entity offering a range of IUDs in these markets, and has been instrumental in increasing distribution of medical abortion, including the combipack.
In Uganda, DKT became the market leader for Emergency Contraception and Medical Abortion combipacks in 2020.
Women First Digital (part of the DK programme) expanded digital resources to promote access to safe medical abortion. 17 countries (of 21) now have dedicated country information pages relating to information on safe abortion and local providers. WFD also launched the worlds first abortion virtual assistant, Ally, who provides non-judgmental information to users currently in three languages - English, French and Hindi - though will expand to include Spanish and Swahili by end of 2021. In 2020, WFD hosted over 2.65 million visits to its three websites: HowToUse, safe2choose, and FindMyMethod.
Key populations:
DKT focused on specific market segments such as adolescents, men who have sex with men, and vulnerable populations. In Liberia, for example, DKT launched a HIV self-test kit and trained key population volunteers in conjunction with the organisation LEGAL. DKT also expanded sales of lubricants in the region and had marketing campaigns for condoms specifically for MSM, including content that includes the LGBTQ community on the pan-sexually inclusive digital resource Find My Method. In Kenya, DKT supported HOYMAS with free condoms.
IDPs/refugees:
DKT provided safe abortion products to the International Rescue Committee (IRC) and Reproductive Health Uganda during 2020, both of which work in refugee settlement areas or have programmes focused on providing reproductive health services to refugees in Uganda. While in Mozambique, DKT was able to maintain a mobile clinic in Cabo Delgado to support IDPs. DKT Kenya also supplies products to IRC for their Somalia programme.
COVID-19 responses during 2020:
Although DKT primarily operates in the private sector, DKT supported local non-governmental organizations and governments during the reporting period, mainly in response to the impact of the COVID-19. For example, DKT fulfilled tenders for the Government of Mali, delivering 8.6 million condoms, 3,2000 implants, and 220,850 units of the Sayana Press injectable. DKT FWACA also delivered 50,000 IUDs to the Government of Senegal and 51,300 IUDs to the Government of Niger. In Uganda, DKT donated over one million Fiesta condoms to the Ministry of Health to distribute to the military, a high-risk group. Similarly, DKT distributed 180,000 IUDs to the Government of Ethiopia and an additional 47,000 to the Government of DRC to reduce likelihood of stock-out. In Liberia, DKT distributed 2,500 MVA kits, 15,000 MA combipacks, and 120,000 misoprostol tablets at zero-cost to public-sector customers to support the dissemination of the National Comprehensive Abortion Care Guidelines.
In Liberia, DKT partnered with the Family Health Division to provide an innovative quick response to the COVID-19 pandemic by opening the Lydia Contact Center as an emergency hotline for pregnant women and those who needed assistance identifying SRH service providers. DKT sent 67,000 bulk SMS messages and conducted a phone survey to identify healthcare providers that remained open and were willing to offer special promotions for SRHR services.
DKT DRC launched a call center and telemedicine platform in collaboration with the PNSR to increase accessibility and ensure continuity of SRH services in the country.
DKT also provided financial training to private clinics and loaned products to those private clinics that provided free SRH services. Through this initiative, DKT distributed 6,500 IUDs to private clinics and trained their providers to expand IUD access in partnership with the Health Federation in Liberia. The purpose was to build capacity of private clinics to enhance distribution (by stimulating the market) and provider knowledge.
DKT Publications 2020
